level.toc-caption: [LCA07 Pt 3.0] Examples of civil jurisdiction beyond that specifically mentioned in the Local Court Act

heading.title: Examples of civil jurisdiction beyond that specifically mentioned in the Local Court Act

p.text: See [LCA07 Pt 3.5]–[LCA07 Pt 3.30], below.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 Pt 3.5] Jurisdiction — injunctions — asset preservation orders

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 Pt 3.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 140, ss 46.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 Pt 8.

The Local Court has no jurisdiction to grant an injunction, as does the District Court pursuant to District Court Act 1973 ss 46 and 140 . However, in Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435; 162 ALR 336; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 , a majority in the High Court (Gaudron, Gummow and Callinan JJ) considered that an inferior court such as the District Court may have an implied power after giving judgment to make an asset preservation order restraining any dealing by the judgment debtors with land they owned which was unrelated to the subject matter of the dispute for such period as was appropriate for the judgment creditor to move promptly to utilise the provisions in the Act with respect to writs of execution (now a writ for the levy of property under CPA Pt 8 ): “Such an order may reasonably have been required as ancillary to the proper object of preventing the recording of adverse dealings in the register before the recording of a writ of execution against the land on the application of the judgment creditor. Other examples may be imagined”. The remarks must be considered obiter because the order under consideration in Pelechowski , above, went beyond this: “The restraint imposed by the District Court was to continue ‘until further order or payment of the verdict.’ The order was not so expressed as to operate in aid of recovery of so much of the judgment debt as might be recouped upon a sale under a writ of execution.”

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 Pt 3.10] Jurisdiction — Competition and Consumer Act 2010 (Cth)

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 Pt 3.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Competition and Consumer Act 2010 Part XI, Part IVB, s 46, s 51ACA, s 79, s 80, s 82, s 82(2), s 86(2), s 86(3), s 86A, s 86A(1), (2), s 87, Schedule 2.

The Competition and Consumer Act 2010 (CCA), which took effect on 1 January 2011 vests the several courts of the States and Territories “with federal jurisdiction within the limits of their several jurisdictions, whether those limits are as to locality, subject-matter or otherwise...with respect to any matter arising under Part IVB in respect of which a civil proceeding is instituted by a person other than the Minister or the Commission”: s 86(2) . However, the various State and Territory courts can only grant a remedy of a kind that the court is able to grant under the law of that State: CCA s 86(3) . Part IVB of the CCA is concerned with Industry Codes, that is, codes “regulating the conduct of participants in an industry towards other participants in the industry or towards consumers in the industry”: CCA s 51ACA . Various remedies are prescribed for a breach of the warranties in CCA, Part IVB , including fines (CCA s 79 ), injunctions (CCA s 80 ), damages (CCA s 82 ) and remedial orders (CCA s 87 ). However, the only remedy which the Local Court has jurisdiction to grant is damages simpliciter, the court's jurisdictional limit then being that specified in the Local Court Act 2007 s 29 , namely $100,000. A claim for breach of the warranties should be pleaded as one for damages for breach of contract. The limitation period is six years from the time the cause of action accrued: CCA s 82(2) .

Under CCA s 86A , the Federal Court may transfer to a court of a State or Territory matters which arise for determination in the proceedings before it under CCA Pt IVB , if the matter arises out of, or is related to a proceeding that is pending in the other court, or it is otherwise in the interests of justice that the matter be determined by the other court: CCA s 86A(1) and (2) . Again, actions may not be so transferred unless the other court “has power to grant the remedies sought before the Federal Court”: TPA s 86A(2) .

For an instance where the Federal Court transferred a matter to the District Court pursuant to the now repealed TPA s 86A (broadly in the same terms as CCA s 86A ), see Nelson v Fernwood Fitness Centre Pty Ltd [1999] FCA 802; BC9903266 . See also Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987 s 10 .

It may be anticipated that the occasions where the Local Court may be called upon to exercise jurisdiction under the CCA will be limited, having regard to the fact that the Federal Magistrates Court has civil jurisdiction with respect to claims under the following provisions of the Competition and Consumer Act 2010 (formerly the Trade Practices Act 1974):
Section 46 (Misuse of Market Power)
Part IVB (Industry Codes)
Part XI (Application of the Australian Consumer Law as a law of the Commonwealth), and
Schedule 2 (Australian Consumer Law).
The Federal Magistrates Court can provide injunctive relief and award damages up to $750,000.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 Pt 3.15] Jurisdiction — Fair Trading Act 1987 (NSW)

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 Pt 3.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Fair Trading Act 1987 Part 3, 4, 5, 5A, 5B, 5C, 5D, 5E, 5F, s 68(1), s 68(1A), s 68(2).

Pursuant to Fair Trading Act 1987 s 68(1) , “a person who suffers loss or damage by conduct of another person that is in contravention of a provision of Part 3 , 4 , 5 (section 43 excepted), 5A , 5B , 5C , 5D , 5E or 5F may recover the amount of the loss or damage by action against the other person or against the person involved in the contravention”. Certain exceptions are specified in Fair Trading Act 1987 s 68(1A) . The action may be commenced at any time within six years after the date on which the cause of action accrued: Fair Trading Act 1987 s 68(2) .

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 Pt 3.20] Jurisdiction — Corporations Act 2001 (Cth)

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 Pt 3.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 1337E(2), s 1337K, s 42B, s 588FF.
(CTH) Judiciary Act 1903 s 79.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.12.

Under Corporations (New South Wales) Act 1990 s 42B , jurisdiction was conferred on inferior courts such as the Local Court in matters arising under the Corporations Law. This situation is continued by Corporations Act 2001 s 1337E . The grant of jurisdiction by legislative enactment overcomes the effect of the decisions in Re Satellite Productions Pty Ltd (in liq); Sky Channel Pty Ltd v Gray (1992) 39 FCR 62; 9 ACSR 519 (Fed C of A) (Lee J); Churcher v Edwardstown Carpets (Reg) (1993) 60 SASR 503; 10 ACSR 405 to the effect that the Local Court had no jurisdiction in such circumstances. The jurisdiction thus conferred is subject to the court's general jurisdictional limits, so far as they relate to the amounts or the value of property with which the court may deal, but is not subject to the court's other jurisdictional limits: Corporations Act 2001 s 1337E(2) .

Judiciary Act 1903 (Cth) s 79 , which provides that “the laws of each State or Territory, including the laws relating to procedure, evidence, and the competency of witnesses, shall, except as otherwise provided by the Constitution or the laws of the Commonwealth, be binding on all Courts exercising federal jurisdiction in that State or Territory in all cases to which they are applicable”, is capable of picking up the rules of court of inferior courts, such as the Local Court and District Court of New South Wales, dealing with extension and abridgment of time (formerly DCR Pt 3 r 2, LCR Pt 4 r 2, presently UCPR r 1.12 ), and Corporations Act 2001 s 588FF , which specifies a time limit on the commencement of actions does not “otherwise provide” to prevent the provisions of the Rules relating to extension of time being “picked up”: Gordon v Tolcher in his capacity as liquidator of Senafield Pty Ltd (in liq) (2006) 231 ALR 582; 60 ACSR 522; [2006] HCA 62; BC200610441 . Corporations Act 2001 s 1337K makes provision for the transfer of proceedings commenced in lower courts such as the Local Court.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 Pt 3.25] Jurisdiction — Workers Compensation Act 1987: claims for refund of overpayments

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 Pt 3.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Workers Compensation Act 1987 s 107, s 58.

heading.title: Jurisdiction — Workers Compensation Act 1987: claims for refund of overpayments

p.text: Workers Compensation Act 1987 s 58 confers jurisdiction upon the Workers Compensation Commission, established under the Workplace Injury Management and Workers Compensation Act 1998, to order a worker to refund overpayments only in the specific circumstances referred to in the section, namely the worker's return to employment affecting the worker's earnings: New South Wales State Brickworks v Abi-Arraj (1995) 38 NSWLR 94; BC9501691 . On the other hand, a claim for moneys overpaid in purported compliance with an award under the Workers Compensation Act 1987 is not a matter “arising under this Act” within Workers Compensation Act 1987 s 107 . It is a claim for moneys recoverable at common law in accordance with equitable principles. The fact that Workers Compensation Act 1987 s 58 has defined circumstances in which the Commission may address an overpayment does not deprive a party who has overpaid moneys in other circumstances (such as a further award which had the effect of terminating a previous award pursuant to which payments had previously been made) of the right to recover such sums in a court of competent jurisdiction. In the circumstances of the case the Local Court had jurisdiction: Carricks Ltd v Pizzaro (1995) 38 NSWLR 274; BC9501848 .

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 Pt 3.30] Jurisdiction — interpreting the validity of subordinate legislation

heading.title: Jurisdiction — interpreting the validity of subordinate legislation

p.text: It has been held that magistrates are not precluded from determining the validity of subordinate legislation: Pennings v Selby (1997) 94 LGERA 1; BC9700937 , declining to follow Bugg v DPP [1993] QB 473; [1993] 2 All ER 815 .

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 Pt 3.35] Confiscation of Proceeds of Crime Act 1989

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 Pt 3.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Confiscation of Proceeds of Crime Act 1989 s 86(7), s 87, s 87(3A), s 87(6).

heading.title: Confiscation of Proceeds of Crime Act 1989

p.text: Several links are spelled out in this Act with the civil jurisdiction of the Local Court sitting in its General Division. Under Confiscation of Proceeds of Crime Act 1989 s 87(3A) , the Local Court may not make a drug proceeds order against a person for an amount that exceeds the jurisdictional limit of the court when sitting in its General Division. Further, under Confiscation of Proceeds of Crime Act 1989 s 87(6) , nothing in s 87 prevents the court from exercising its jurisdiction in relation to a freezing notice issued in relation to land or in relation to property whose value exceeds the jurisdictional limit of the Court sitting in its General Division. And under s 86(7) , proceedings before the Court on an application for a forfeiture order or drug proceeds order, or on an application for confirmation or setting aside of a freezing notice, are to be dealt with by the court sitting in its General Division.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29] s 29 Jurisdictional limit of Court

p.text: For the purposes of this Part, the jurisdictional limit of the Court is:
$100,000, when sitting in its General Division, and
$10,000, when sitting in its Small Claims Division.
However, the jurisdictional limit of the Court, when sitting in its General Division, in relation to a claim for damages arising from personal injury or death is $60,000.
[s 29 subst Act 135 of 2010 Sch 15[2], effective 7 December 2010]

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29.5] Section 29(2) damages for personal injury and death

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 29.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 44(1)(d) , [DCA s 44.5].

heading.title: Section 29(2) damages for personal injury and death

p.text: In practice these matters will be heard in the District Court which has unlimited jurisdiction in such matters: District Court Act 1973 s 44(1)(d) and commentary in Ritchie's Uniform Civil Procedure NSW at [DCA s 44.5] .
In this Part, money claim means a claim for recovery of any debt, demand or damages (whether liquidated or unliquidated).
[s 29A insrt Act 135 of 2010 Sch 15[2], effective 7 December 2010]

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29A.5] Money claim — meaning

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 29A.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 30(a).
(NSW) Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972 ss 5, 6, 7.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 134.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 23.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 [s 21.10].

Under LCA 2007 s 30(a) , the Local Court only has jurisdiction in respect of a “money claim”, that is “a claim for recovery of any debt, demand or damage (whether liquidated or unliquidated)”, which is the classic exercise of a common law jurisdiction.
However, Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972 ss 5 , 6 and 7 provide that:

In all matters in which there was immediately before the commencement of this Act or is, any conflict or variance between the rules of equity and the rules of common law relating to the same matter, the rules of equity shall prevail.

Every inferior court shall in every proceeding before it give such and the like effect to every ground of defence, equitable or legal, in as full and ample a manner as might and ought to be done in the like case by the Supreme Court under the Supreme Court Act 1970.

This Act does not enlarge the jurisdiction of any court as regards the nature or extent of the relief available in that court, but any court may, for the purpose of giving effect to sections 5 and 6 of this Act, postpone the grant of any relief, or grant relief subject to such terms and conditions as the nature of the case requires.

These provisions do not confer jurisdiction upon inferior courts to institute proceedings which might properly be commenced only in the equity jurisdiction of the Supreme Court. Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972 s 7 says specifically that the Act “does not enlarge” jurisdiction. The result is that, although all inferior courts may now entertain every ground of defence, equitable or legal, there has been no enlargement of the jurisdiction of any inferior court as regards the nature and extent of the relief available in those courts: United Telecasters Sydney Ltd v Hardy (1991) 23 NSWLR 323 at 332 ; see also Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435; 162 ALR 336 at 338; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 per the majority (Gaudron, Gummow and Callinan JJ).

The provisions of Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972 s 5 are directed only to those courts invested with jurisdiction to administer simultaneously both systems of law, legal and equitable: Joblin v Carney (1975) 1 BPR 9642 noted; [1976] ACLD 170. While the District Court has a limited jurisdiction to grant specific performance (eg under District Court Act 1973 s 134 ), the Local Court has no authority to administer the rules of equity.

Circumstances may arise where a plaintiff sues for rent due under a lease, or money payable under an agreement, where the lease, contract or other document under consideration is ineffectual at law to pass the estate which it purports to convey, but which nevertheless a court of competent jurisdiction, such as the Supreme Court in its equitable jurisdiction, would enforce by a decree of specific performance. If such a defence is raised, to accede to the plaintiff's claim is tantamount to granting specific performance of the contract or agreement: Walsh v Lonsdale (1882) 21 Ch D 9 . In such a circumstance the appropriate course for the Local Court to take is to postpone relief under s 7 pending an application by the defendant to the Supreme Court: Meagher, Gummow and Lehane, Equity: Doctrines and Remedies, 2nd ed, LexisNexis Butterworths, Sydney, para 249. See also Moore v Dimond [1929] SASR 274 . The Local Court has no power to adjust the rights of contracting parties where it is satisfied that a court of equity would interfere to adjust those rights according to the real intention of the parties at the time they made the contract. Local Courts are courts of law and have no equitable jurisdiction: Shaw v Baker (1885) 19 SALR 69 ; Buzera Pty Ltd v Mezan Enterprises Pty Ltd (1998) NSW ConvR ¶55-851; BC9800722. Having regard to the decision in Joblin v Carney (1975) 1 BPR 9642 , the decision in Douglas v Hill (1909) SALR 28 is not the law in this state.

“The term ‘equitable ground of defence’ in s 6 of the Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972 is referable to an equity such as unclean hands or laches which was developed in equity as a disentitlement of the plaintiff from relief in that jurisdiction, whereas the ‘defence’ in Walsh v Lonsdale, above, is essentially a claim asserted by the defendant to independent relief which must be made out before he can defend the action of the plaintiff” in proceedings then current: Meagher, Gummow and Lehane, above. For example, in Batley v Local Court of New South Wales (NSWSC, Bruce J, 4 February 1998, unreported), an equitable estoppel defence was available by virtue of Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972 s 6 to a party resisting a claim to recover an option fee paid on a void conveyancing. However, a claim for damages for use and occupation made pursuant to an arrangement between parties which was never properly formalised in circumstances where the plaintiff accepted the defendant's repudiation of that arrangement for the purposes of mitigating his or her damage, and thereafter sued for damages is a liquidated demand which does not depend upon the court making an order for specific performance, by implication or otherwise, and is therefore within the jurisdiction of the Local Court: Hills v King (NSWLC, Elms M, No 14041/88, 5 September 1988, unreported), reproduced in guide card “Practice Decisions” at [456,140] . Similarly, a claim for use and occupation of land in the nature of mesne profits may be maintained in the Local Court where the period in respect of which the claim is made is finite and the claim does not depend upon equitable rights: Brand v Pallisar Pty Ltd (NSWLC, Elms M, No 8293/88, 20 April 1990, unreported) reproduced in guide card "Practice Decisions" at [456,105] . Such claims are deemed liquidated, notwithstanding that the claim is for a “reasonable” occupation fee: Beech v Potter (1904) 29 VLR 830; 10 ALR 124 ; Ex parte Matthews (1918) 35 WN (NSW) 13 , cited at [LCA07 s 29.20] . However, a claim for an occupation fee arising by implication as the result of equity intervening and providing that interest should be paid on the unpaid purchase price (see Miaoli Holdings Pty Ltd v Somerville (NSWSC, Cohen J, No 2194/87, 14 February 1990, unreported, BC9002731)) cannot be maintained in the Local Court. On the other hand, the fact that the basis for the claim for payment of money is said to be the existence of an equitable lease does not necessarily require that the court involved must exercise any equitable jurisdiction: Buzera Pty Ltd v Mezan Enterprises Pty Ltd (1998) NSW ConvR ¶55-851; BC9800722 (claim for unpaid rent following an alleged agreement for lease or alternatively an equitable lease; application to transfer proceedings from Local Court to Supreme Court under Supreme Court Act 1970 s 23 refused). A claim for contribution arising under a guarantee is available both at common law and in equity. At common law the guarantor would need to show that he or she had already paid more than the just proportion of the principal debt. Such a claim may be made on a common money count claiming money paid for the use of another and was thus cognisable at common law. If in such an action, the plaintiff simply pleads the facts, the court must identify the cause of action to determine whether the right alleged is common law or equitable: Hunyh v Swanson [1999] NSWSC 490; BC9900622 . In Price v HP Mercantile Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 632; BC200705088 , Fullerton J expressed the obiter view that the defendant could not rely upon an equitable assignment to recover a debt, basing her decision on a separate legal assignment thereof. As to the distinction between money sued for under an agreement to sell a partnership share (which is within the jurisdiction of the Local Court, as being a claim for a debt) and a claim made by a partner in the capacity of a partnership agreement requiring the taking of a partnership account, which is not, see Zisis v Knighton [2008] NSWCA 42; BC200802110 , noted at [LCA07 s 29.10] .

An equitable set-off may be relied upon in the Local Court whether or not the contrary claims are ‘mutual’ in the sense required by the Civil Procedure Act 2005, and irrespective of whether or not both claims involve liquidated demands: Concrete Equipment Australia (Trading) Pty Ltd v Bonfiglioli Transmission (Aust) Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 393; BC201002819 at [24] per Barr AJ. See also the commentary to the CPA at [s 21.10] .

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29A.10] ″Money claim″ — ″Debt, demand or damage, whether liquidated or unliquidated″

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 29A.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.3.

heading.title: "Money claim" — "Debt, demand or damage, whether liquidated or unliquidated"

p.text: The distinction between a debt or liquidated demand on the one hand and unliquidated damages on the other goes back to the forms of action, that "curious admixture" of substantive and procedural law which governed the English legal system until the mid-19th century. In an oft-quoted statement of the distinction, Odgers says that:

[W]henever the amount to which the plaintiff is entitled (if he is entitled to anything) can be ascertained by calculation or fixed by any scale of charges or other positive data, it is said to be liquidated or `made clear'. But an action in which the amount to be recovered depends upon all the circumstances of the case, and no-one can say positively beforehand whether the plaintiff will recover a farthing, or 40 shillings, or £100, is an action for unliquidated damages:

Walter Blake Odgers, Principles of Pleading and Practice, 12th ed, 1939, Stevens & Sons Ltd, pp 47–8, cited with approval by Knox CJ and Starke J in Spain v Union Steamship Co of New Zealand Ltd (1923) 32 CLR 138 at 142; 29 ALR 311; BC2300033 , and by Sholl J in Alexander v Ajax Insurance Co Ltd [1956] VLR 436; [1956] ALR 1077 .

Furthermore, “in an action on a bill of exchange or promissory note the amount of the verdict, if it be for the plaintiff at all, can be reckoned beforehand. But in an action of libel, it is open to the jury to award the plaintiff a farthing, or 40 shillings, or £100; and no-one can say beforehand what the precise figure will be”: Odgers, "Damages" Encyclopaedia of the Laws of England (1908), London, vol IV at p 102, also cited by Sholl J in Alexander , above, at 440.

Therefore, “in order to be ‘liquidated’, the sum claimed (save no doubt in the case of a claim for a reasonable amount, where that could have been sued for under the common counts) must, in the opinion of [the] court, have been agreed upon in some binding and conclusive fashion. At all events it had to be so fixed for the purpose of being set-off”: Alexander , above, at 442. Upon its proper construction, an agreement to sell and divide a partnership share gave rise to a debt, alternatively a claim for liquidated damages, which may be sued upon without an account being taken, since the amounts sought to be recovered under the partnership agreement were "certain and ascertainable". Therefore, the Local Court had jurisdiction to entertain the claim: Zisis v Knighton [2008] NSWCA 42; BC200802110 .

There is a distinction between a debt and other liquidated claim. In circumstances where a party defaulted under a contract requiring him to pay regular monetary rental instalments for the hire of equipment, for the primary obligations of the party in default there is substituted by operation of law a secondary obligation to pay to the other party a sum of money to compensate him for the loss he has sustained following the defaulting party’s failure to perform the primary obligation. These damages are a secondary obligation and survive the discharge of the contract; they are not a “debt” but in the circumstances of the case nothing hangs upon the distinction; UCPR r 6.3 requires the same originating process for each: Mantoufeh v Enterprise Finance Solutions Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 1144; BC200909757 esp at [23] . An innocent party to a contract wrongly repudiated by the other party must elect whether to accept the repudiation of treat the contract as still on foot in which case he is limited to his right to sue for damages for breach of a non-essential warranty: Mehmet v Kesidis [2009] NSWSC 1087; BC200909759 .

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29A.15] ″Debt or liquidated demand in money″

p.text: In Alexander v Ajax Insurance Co Ltd [1956] VLR 436; [1956] ALR 1077 , Sholl J traced the history of the phrase "debt or liquidated demand in money" to the First Report of the Common Law Commissioners, 1851 (p 38 at Appendix A) and concluded that the meaning of the phrase remained the same down to the present day, subject to certain specific areas of inclusion or exclusion since made by the courts. The phrase embraced, and embraces, "any claim:
for which the action of debt would lie;

for which an indebitatus (or 'common') count would lie — including those cases formerly covered by the quantum meruit or quantum valebat counts, notwithstanding that the only agreement implied between the parties in such cases was for payment at a 'reasonable' rate;

for which covenant, or special assumpsit would lie, provided that the claim was for a specific amount, not involving in the calculation thereof elements the selection whereof was dependent on the opinion of the jury": Alexander , above, at 445.

In certain cases the law will imply a promise on behalf of the defendant to pay a reasonable amount for work done or goods sold, notwithstanding that a fixed price has not been agreed upon by the parties (the old quantum meruit and quantum valebat counts). For reasons only explainable historically the reasonable price which the law says is payable for work done or goods sold where the contract fixes no price, is not unliquidated damages but is regarded as "an ascertainable sum of a liquidated kind and hence capable of giving rise to a debt": A F Rath, Principles and Precedents of Pleading, Law Book Co, 1961, p 25. The eight common money counts — goods sold and delivered; goods bargained and sold; work done and materials provided; money lent; money paid; money had and received; interest forborne; accounts stated — are appropriate only in the case of a debt or liquidated demand and are inappropriate if the plaintiff's claim is for unliquidated damages. However, the issue of an ordinary statement of claim in such circumstances will never be fatal to the plaintiff's claim: Di Muzio v De Vries (NSWSC, Cross J, 30 September 1983, unreported) and may be cured by amendment. Under the CPA, the distinction between ordinary statement of claim and statement of liquidated claim is now redundant, as elaborated upon in [LCA07 s 29.35] below. On the subject of money claims generally, see also the discussion in Court Forms, Precedents and Pleadings NSW, LexisNexis Butterworths, vol 2, behind guide card "Money Matters", together with precedents.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29A.20] Liquidated demands

p.text: For other categories of claim which the law deems as liquidated rather than unliquidated demands see:

Beech v Potter (1904) 29 VLR 830 , a claim for use and occupation of land, per Madden J at 832: "Where there is a transaction and the contract has reached such a stage that everything is complete except payment of the consideration, there arises an action of indebitatus assumpsit — an action for debt or money demand. In the present case ‘use and occupation' is the form in which the plaintiff sues and that has always been an action which came within the category of debt. It is said that it ought not to come within the category because this is an action for an unliquidated money demand — an indefinite sum — that it is a claim for an amount representing the reasonable value of the premises and is not specific. But the same criticism would apply to a case of goods sold and delivered, or work and labour done, or interest upon money, or money had and received, in many of which the amount has to be ascertained, because no specific amount has been agreed upon. All these are unquestionably actions of debt or for a liquidated demand, notwithstanding the actual amount has not been determined beforehand, but has to be estimated on stated terms, if the plaintiff is right";
Ex parte Matthews (1918) 35 WN (NSW) 13 , another claim for use and occupation of land;
Lagos v Grunwaldt [1910] 1 KB 41 , a claim upon a quantum meruit for professional work done as a solicitor;

Segur v Franklin (1934) 34 SR (NSW) 67 at 72; 51 WN (NSW) 31 at 33 , a claim by an arbitrator on a quantum meruit, per Jordan CJ: "I think that it is clearly settled that if one party to a contract repudiates his liabilities under it, the other party may treat such repudiation as an invitation to him to regard himself as discharged from the further performance of the contract; and he may accept this invitation and treat the contract as at an end, except for the purposes of an action for damages for breach of contract … or in a proper case, an action for a quantum meruit. Where a wrongful repudiation has the effect of preventing the other party from becoming entitled to receive remuneration for services already rendered, which remuneration, according to the terms of the contract he is entitled to receive only if the contract is wholly carried into effect, the innocent party, who has elected to treat the contract as at an end may, instead of suing for damages, maintain an action to recover a quantum meruit for the services which he has rendered before it came to an end. Such an action is not regarded as an action for an unliquidated claim but an action for a debt or liquidated demand";

Workman, Clark & Co Ltd v Lloyd Brazileno [1908] KB 968; (1908) 99 LT 477 ; McDonald v Dennys Lascelles Ltd (1933) 48 CLR 457; [1933] ALR 381; BC3300017 ; Ruwald v Halling (1927) 27 SR (NSW) 334 , claims for instalments of the purchase price of a ship and upon a contract for the purchase of land;

Mallinson v Scottish Australian Investment Co Ltd (1920) 28 CLR 66; 26 ALR 225; [1920] HCA 51; BC2000035 a claim by an employee to recover the difference between the amount of wages paid pursuant to a contract of employment and that payable under an award;
Automatic Fire Sprinklers Pty Ltd v Watson (1946) 72 CLR 435; [1946] ALR 390; (1946) 20 ALJR 189; BC4600020 , a claim for wages by an employee dismissed without approval;
GL Baker Ltd v Barclays Bank Ltd [1956] 3 All ER 519, a claim for the conversion of a specified sum of money;

Latec Finance Pty Ltd v Wilkins (1963) 80 WN (NSW) 1333 , a claim for compensation as "liquidated damage" calculated in accordance with s 5 of the Hire Purchase Agreement Act 1941–1957, following the repossession of a motor vehicle after breach of a hire purchase agreement;
Lombard Australia Ltd v Atkins (No 1) (1963) 1 DCR (NSW) 25, a claim to recover the amount due under a hire purchase agreement where default made and hiring terminated.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29A.25] Motor vehicle property damage claims

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 29A.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 29(2).
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 44(1)(d).

See Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], esp cl 18 “Maximum Cost Orders in the General Division where liability is not in issue” and cl 19 “Maximum Cost Orders where liability and quantum are in issue”, both of which are expressed to apply to motor vehicle accidents. PN 6 of 2007 contained a clause (cl 6) containing standard directions as to the calling of expert witness evidence in such matters, in addition to the Standard Directions made pursuant to the then Practice Note 1 of 2005, which has not been reproduced in the current Practice Note. Instead, there is now a clause which is apparently intended to deal with expert evidence in all civil matters in the Local Court (cl 16).

Clause 16 follows almost verbatim Practice Note SC Gen 10 “Supreme Court — Single Expert Witness” dated 17 August 2005: see [SC Gen 10] behind the guidecard “Practice Notes”. It seems strangely ill-suited to proceedings in the Local Court. The Supreme Court Practice Note applies by its terms to claims for damages “for personal injury or disability”. Clause 16 does not say so, but it is clear that it can virtually only relate to such proceedings. However, the Local Court’s jurisdiction in claims for damages for personal injury or death remains at $60,000 (Local Court Act, s 29(2) ), and the number of personal injury cases commenced in the Local Court (particularly those involving Griffiths v Kerkemeyer and Sullivan v Gordon type damages mentioned in the Practice Note) will remain negligible, if indeed there are any at all, since the District Court has jurisdiction in “any motor vehicle accident, irrespective of the amount claimed” (DCA s 44(1)(d) ), and is specifically geared for such claims. Without a significant stretch of the imagination, it is difficult to see how the specifics of cl 16 can apply at all to building type cases in the Local Court where a Scott Schedule was formerly utilised, nor to motor vehicle property damage claims which were formerly the subject of Local Court Practice Note 6 of 2007 “General Division — Quantum of Damages (Motor Vehicle Accidents)”.
PN 1 of 2005 cl 11, contained a provision on the subject of expert evidence which read as follows:

So far as is practicable to do so without compromising the interests of justice, expert evidence is to be given on an issue in proceedings by a single expert engaged by the parties or appointed by the Court. R 31.17(d).
Parties must seek directions from the Court before calling any expert witness.
Directions may be sought at Call-over before a Magistrate. If a Call Over is held before a Registrar, the matter is to be referred to a Magistrate for directions.
If, after Call-over, a party decides that it is necessary to call an expert witness, he/she may apply to the court for directions by notice of motion or pursuant to liberty to restore.
It is the responsibility of the parties or their legal representatives to inform the Court that expert evidence will be called.
The Court may at any time give such directions as it considers appropriate in relation to the use of expert evidence in proceedings. Rule 31.20

It is submitted that this clause is far more suited to the occasion than cl 16 because it also contains machinery provisions governing how the clause is to operate, which cl 16 is lacking, and cl 16 has a personal injury context ill-suited to the multifarious kinds of matters under consideration in the Local Court.

As previously mentioned, PN 6 of 2007 also contained a clause dealing with expert evidence in motor vehicle property damage claims in addition to the Standard Directions made pursuant to Practice Note 1 of 2005 as follows:
Each witness to be called to give expert evidence for each party is required to confer (“the Conference”) at least twenty eight days prior to the Review Date.

That is a result of the Conference the witnesses to give expert evidence on quantum of damages are required to state with precision in writing in the form of a Scott Schedule, no later than fourteen days prior to the Review Date, the points of agreement and differences between them.

If the witnesses to be called by the parties to give expert evidence do not agree on all issues between them, the parties will, before the Review, agree on a “Parties Single Expert” to report on the points of difference between the parties.

In the absence of agreement between the parties of the appointment of a “Parties Single Expert”, the Court at the Review will appoint an expert from a list to be provided by the parties, to inquire into and report of the points of difference between the parties.
That unless the Court otherwise orders, there will be a maximum of one hour allowed for the Cross-Examination of the Parties Single Expert or the Court Appointed Expert by each party.
A maximum of thirty minutes will be allowed for each party to address on the evidence before the Court.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29A.27] Historical

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 29A.27] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 60.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.23.

PN 6 of 2007 had its origins in the context of a number of decisions which had journeyed to the Supreme Court, and in one instance, Stocovaz v Fung [2007] NSWCA 199; BC200706640 , to the NSW Court of Appeal. In that case, at [2] of Basten JA's judgment, the court was taken to a judgment of Magistrate Lulham in a matter of Kenn v Pickard (unreported, 16 September 2005) where his Honour noted that the amount in issue was frequently between $3,000 and $4,000. The dispute may take three or four days to be heard. His Honour commented at [26]: “It is hard to escape the conclusion that in many ways the court has become a pawn in the commercial war presently being waged between various insurance companies and between various insurance companies and repairers. Certainly the amount of time such matters are consuming of the courts' valuable time is a matter of great concern. Further, it is difficult to see how the very considerable costs being incurred can be in the financial interests of the parties”; and at [29] of Handley JA's judgment with whom Hoeben JA agreed: “It appears that the Local Court has been flooded with small claims of this kind and the former practice of motor vehicle insurers avoiding such litigation by entering into knock for knock agreements has been abandoned”. Two other decisions in the Supreme Court Administrative List are also worthy of note. These instances involved litigation over comparatively small sums of money which took days of court time and “generated excessive and unnecessary legal costs and a waste of Court resources”, prompting Harrison As J to comment that “(t)here is meant to be some measure of proportionality between the amount of the dispute and the costs incurred in the litigation of that dispute — see s 60 Civil Procedure Act 2005 (NSW)”: Prats v Petroni [2007] NSWSC 622; BC200704743 at [6]; Sharkawy v Toman [2007] NSWSC 621; BC200704752 at [6]. These decisions also held that the plaintiff's (in the Local Court proceedings) expert was not an expert witness for the purpose of UCPR r 31.23 when he examined the vehicle and prepared his original report four days after the accident (following Kirch Communications Pty Ltd v Gene Engineering Pty Ltd [2002] NSWSC 485; BC200203021 at [11] per Campbell J), but that he became so when he prepared his affidavit for the purpose of the court proceedings. During the hearing, he was not cross-examined as to the fact that he had not adhered to the expert's code of conduct, and so his evidence stood, its weight being a matter for the magistrate. The Court of Appeal decision in Stocovaz v Fung, above, laid down the principle that there are in fact two caps on the plaintiff's recovery: "He is not entitled to recover more than his actual cost, and he is not entitled to recover that cost to the extent that it was extravagant or unreasonable": at [39] per Handley JA; Hoeben JA agreeing.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29A.30] Claims in foreign currency

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 29A.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 69.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 100, s 100(1), (2), s 101(2), section 96.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 16.6(2)(d), r 6.11(7)(b).

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29A.30.5] The claim itself

p.text: A claim may be made to recover a sum of money in a foreign currency whether the sum claimed is to recover a debt (Miliangos v George Frank (Textiles) Ltd [1976] AC 443; [1975] 3 All ER 801 ) or represents damages for breach of contract and for tort: The Despina R [1979] AC 685; [1979] 1 All ER 421 ; applied in Mitsui Osk Lines Ltd v The Ship Mineral Transporter [1983] 2 NSWLR 564 . There would appear to be no difficulty in applying these principles to a court of inferior jurisdiction such as the Local Court, on the basis that damages should generally be paid in the currency that best represents the plaintiff's loss. However, evidence may be required at the time the statement of claim is filed to show that the claim falls within the limits of the court's jurisdiction unless this is obvious. If the plaintiff's claim is liquidated according to the criterion enunciated by Sholl J in Alexander v Ajax Insurance Co Ltd [1956] VLR 436; [1956] ALR 1077 (at [LCA07 s 65.1.15]), it does not become unliquidated because the claim is made in foreign currency, since such a claim is capable of being ascertained by calculation or by reference to a determinate rate of exchange: Seymour v Sherian (NSWCA, Moffit P, Mahoney and Priestley JJA, No 417/1983, 15 November 1983, unreported) applying Spain v Union Steamship Co of New Zealand Ltd (1923) 32 CLR 138 at 142; 29 ALR 311; BC2300033 , and State Advances Recovery Office of the Republic of South Africa v Fine [1968] 1 NSWR 702; (1968) 87 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 448 . Where the debt was contracted overseas, and where the contract is made overseas and the defendant resides or is based overseas, the Local Court may well be without jurisdiction, nor may substituted service of the statement of claim be possible: (see the notes to LCA 2007 s 69 below at [LCA07 s 69] ff).

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29A.30.10] Judgments in foreign currency and enforcement

heading.title: Judgments in foreign currency and enforcement

p.text: A judgment ought to be in the currency that best expresses the judgment creditor's loss: Maschinenfabrik Augsburg-Nurenburg v Altikar Pty Ltd [1984] 3 NSWLR 152; (1984) ASC ¶55-357 . This applies whether the plaintiff's claim is to recover a debt (Miliangos v George Frank (Textiles) Ltd [1976] AC 443; [1975] 3 All ER 801 ), or represents damages for breach of contract and for tort: The Despina R [1979] AC 685; [1979]1 All ER 421 ; Mitsui Osk Lines Ltd v The Ship Mineral Transporter [1983] 2 NSWLR 564 . If the plaintiff's loss is in multiple currencies, there is nothing to prevent a judgment being recorded in multiple currencies. Thus, in Norsemeter Holdings AS v Boele (No 3) [2002] NSWSC 390; BC200203331 , the plaintiff's principal loss was sustained in Swedish currency, whereas the costs of pushing the court proceedings in the Norwegian courts was incurred in Norwegian currency. Einstein J recorded a judgment in the one proceeding for the principal and interest in one currency and costs in the other. Where judgment is expressed in a foreign currency it should be in a form which permits payment in the equivalent amount of local currency converted as at the date when leave is given to enforce the judgment in terms of the local currency: Schorsch Meir GmbH v Hennin [1975] QB 416 at 425; [1975] 1 All ER 152 , approved in Miliangos v George Frank (Textiles) Ltd [1976] AC 443 at 468; [1975] 3 All ER 801 . The form of judgment expressed in Schorsch Meir was: "'It is adjudged this day that the defendant pay to the plaintiff' so much in foreign currency (being the currency of the contract) 'or the sterling equivalent at the time of payment'." The Court of Appeal went on at 425: "If the defendant does not honour the judgment the plaintiff can apply for leave to enforce it. He should file an affidavit showing the rate of exchange as at the date of the application and give the amount of the dollars converted into sterling at that date. Then leave will be given to enforce payment of that sum". For Australian purposes, the above references to sterling should be understood as Australian dollars.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29A.30.15] Pre-judgment interest on amounts claimed in foreign currency

heading.title: Pre-judgment interest on amounts claimed in foreign currency

p.text: CPA s 100 gives the court a discretion to order pre-judgment interest "at such rate as it thinks fit": CPA s 100(1) and (2) . Under UCPR r 6.11(7)(b) , in the case of a liquidated claim, a claim for an order for interest up to judgment must specify: the rate or rates at which interest is claimed, "which may, if the plaintiff so chooses, be expressed by reference to the corresponding rate of interest prescribed by Schedule 7 for the purposes of section 96 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005". If the plaintiff's claim is made pursuant to a contract, the contract may itself make provision for the payment of interest. If it does not, pre-judgment interest awarded on a judgment ought to be calculated so as best to express the loss to the judgment creditor in being kept out of its money (Batchelor v Burke (1981) 148 CLR 448; 35 ALR 15; 55 ALJR 494 at 19; BC8100074 per Gibbs J).

If a successful party opts for a judgment in foreign currency, it ordinarily commits itself to whatever rate of interest obtains in the context of that currency, upon the basis that it would reasonably borrow that currency in the foreign jurisdiction to replace its loss pending judgment: Maschinenfabrik Augsburg-Nurenburg v Altikar Pty Ltd [1984] 3 NSWLR 152; (1984) ASC ¶55-357 ; Miliangos v George Frank (Textiles) Ltd (No 2) [1977] QB 489 at 485; [1976] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 434 at 435 ; Nishina Trading Co Ltd v Chiyoda Fire & Marine Insurance Co Ltd [1968] 3 All ER 712 at 720; [1968] 1 WLR 1325 at 1336 per Donaldson J; Swiss Bank Corp v New South Wales (1993) 33 NSWLR 63; BC9304088 ; on appeal in State Bank of New South Wales v Swiss Bank Corp (1995) 39 NSWLR 350; BC9505314 (interest rates should be calculated by reference to US dollar rates — the rates applicable to the judgment of the currency — rather than Australian dollar rates); Westpac Banking Corp v MV Stone Gemini [1999] FCA 917; BC9903829 (currency of the transaction in US dollars; interest therefore ordered to be calculated by reference to US dollars borrowing rates; proper measure of compensation was amount plaintiff was out of pocket by not having the amount of the judgment in US dollars from relevant date to judgment; submission that Australian rates should apply because in order to compensate it for the loss the plaintiff would be expected and entitled to cover its loss by raising funds in Australian dollars at Australian rates rejected; held, that the ordinary rule should apply). Compare Mitsui Osk Lines Ltd v The Ship Mineral Transporter [1983] 2 NSWLR 564 at 569 per Yeldham J, but see The Funabashi [1972] 2 All ER 181 per Dunn J. The rationale behind this view is that, local rates being (at the time) higher than those prevailing in the overseas nations then under consideration, an award calculated in accordance with local interest rates would represent a distinct windfall. “Rather than representing the true amount of the exporter's loss, the plaintiff would be receiving the benefit of the higher rate of inflation suffered in Australia as compared with West Germany without any regard being had to the fact that, had payment been made in the ordinary course, the deutschmarks would have been remitted to the exporter at the proper time and would have, presumably been employed by the exporter in the ordinary course of business and earned interest at the rates obtaining in West Germany": Maschinenfabrik , above, at 153 per Rogers J.

Should the relevant overseas interest rate be higher than those prevailing in New South Wales, it is submitted that the rate of pre-judgment interest is a matter for the court. For an instance where pre-judgment interest was awarded at a rate other than that of the contract and the judgment, each of which were in Maltese pounds, see Helmsing Schiffahrts GmbH & Co KG v Malta Drydocks Corp [1977] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 444 (interest awarded at German rates, since the plaintiff's business was in Germany and the plaintiff had to find the equivalent sum from other sources in Germany). Kerr J distinguished Miliangos v George Frank (Textiles) Ltd (No 2) [1977] QB 489 at 485; [1976] 3 All ER 599; [1976] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 434 at 435 , a case in which the plaintiff was a Swiss national carrying on business in Switzerland, and the contract was governed by Swiss law and it expressed the price in Swiss francs, saying that in the case before him it would be a capricious result if interest was to be awarded at English rates when the English currency had no real nexus with the transaction or the loss. In Norsemeter Holdings AS v Boele (No 3) [2002] NSWSC 390; BC200203331 , Einstein J awarded pre-judgment interest at the then current Norwegian rate of 12 per cent. Post judgment, the prescribed rates in Sch 7 apply or "such other rate as the court may order": CPA s 101(2) .

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29A.30.20] Default judgment — claims in foreign currency

heading.title: Default judgment — claims in foreign currency

p.text: There would appear to be no impediment to the entry of default judgment upon a claim made in foreign currency, where the court is one of inferior jurisdiction such as the District Court and the Local Court. The matter was expressly left unanswered in Seymour v Sherian (NSWCA, Moffit P, Mahoney and Priestley JJA, No 417/83, 15 November 1983, unreported), a case where default judgment was signed in the District Court in respect of a claim made in pounds sterling. The operative principle is that a judgment ought to be in the currency that best expresses the judgment creditor's loss: Maschinenfabrik Augsburg-Nurenburg v Altikar Pty Ltd [1984] 3 NSWLR 152; (1984) ASC ¶55-357 . The plaintiff's affidavit under UCPR r 16.6(2)(d) should state details as to how the interest is calculated and at what rate and why this rate is considered appropriate.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29A.35] Claims for unliquidated damages

p.text: Claims for unliquidated damages are such as do not constitute claims for a debt or liquidated demand. Thus a policy of insurance is only a promise of indemnity giving a right of action for unliquidated damages in case of non-payment (William Pickersgill & Son Ltd v London Provincial Marine & General Insurance Co Ltd [1912] 3 KB 614 at 622 per Hamilton J, citing Pellas & Co v Neptune Marine Insurance Co (1879) 5 CPD 34 ) unless the policy is one whereby the insurer has agreed, in the event of a total loss of the insured property, to pay an agreed sum whatever the value of the insured property may have been: Alexander v Ajax Insurance Co Ltd [1956] VLR 436; [1956] ALR 1077 . Even in the case of an agreed value type policy, the claim will still be unliquidated if it is incumbent upon the plaintiff to prove that there is in fact a total loss giving rise to the claim for indemnity under the policy, that is, unless there has been an admission or an adjustment of the claim by the insurer prior to action which would enable the plaintiff to sue upon an account stated: Alexander , above, at 445 et seq.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29A.40] Procedural distinctions between liquidated and unliquidated claims under the UCPR

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 29A.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 30, rr 14.13, r 16.3, rr 16.4, 16.5, r 16.6, r 16.7, r 16.8, rr 6.5, 6.6, Pt 1, Pts 2, 3.
(NSW) Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act 1970 s 75A(2).

heading.title: Procedural distinctions between liquidated and unliquidated claims under the UCPR

p.text: The distinction between a claim for liquidated damages and one for unliquidated damages is no longer as significant as it was under the now repealed Local Courts (Civil Claims) Rules 1988. Then the distinction was significant because it governed the formalities a plaintiff employed to initiate his or her claim, and the procedural consequences which flowed thereafter. A plaintiff suing for a debt or liquidated demand initiated proceedings by Statement of Liquidated Claim, and, in the case of unliquidated claims, commenced by Ordinary Statement of Claim. Now, proceedings are commenced by “Statement of Claim” regardless as to whether the claim is liquidated or unliquidated: UCPR Sch 6 Pt 1 (or by Summons in other circumstances not relevant for present purposes: UCPR Sch 6 Pts 2 and 3 ). In any event, even under the old rules, a court could not set aside a proceeding on the basis that, although not constituting an action for the recovery of a debt or liquidated demand, it had been commenced by Statement of Liquidated Claim: Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act 1970 s 75A(2) . And under the new regime, the commencement of process by the wrong form of process (Statement of Claim or Summons) will never be fatal to the plaintiff's claim, and the proceedings may be continued under UCPR rr 6.5 and 6.6 .

Where the defendant is in default, under the UCPR the procedures differ somewhat depending as to whether the claim is liquidated or unliquidated, as was the case under the old rules. A plaintiff applies for judgment under r 16.3 “according to the nature of his or her claim”. If the claim is liquidated, the plaintiff follows the default procedure set out in UCPR r 16.6 . A plaintiff seeking unliquidated damages applies for judgment under UCPR r 16.7 (possibly also UCPR r 16.8 ), judgment is awarded for damages to be assessed and the plaintiff is then required to prove his or her damage under Pt 30 . (As to default judgment on claims for possession of land and default judgment on claims for detention of goods, see UCPR rr 16.4 and 16.5 respectively.)

Claims for the recovery of the cost of repair of a motor vehicle, or the value, less any salvage value, of a motor vehicle, or the towing of a motor vehicle, where the repair, loss or towing is a consequence of damage alleged to have been sustained as a result of the negligence of the defendant or the defendant's servant or agent, (and claims for damages for certain other property negligently damaged) are unliquidated, but for the purposes of seeking default judgment, are deemed to be liquidated: UCPR rr 14.13 and 16.6 . Not included under the banner of liquidated claims are suits in which a claim for demurrage is included. Claims including this component will be set down for damages to be assessed and will then need to be proved by evidence.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 29A.45] Penalty or unliquidated damages

p.text: "The criterion of whether a sum — be it called penalty or damages — is truly liquidated damages, and as such not to be interfered with by the court, or is truly a penalty which covers the damage if proved, but does not assess it, is to be found whether the sum stipulated for can or cannot be regarded as a `genuine pre-estimate of the creditor's probable or possible interest in the due performance of the principal obligation'. The indicia of this question will vary according to circumstances. Enormous disparity of the sum to any conceivable loss will point one way, while the fact of the payment being in terms proportionate to the loss will point to the other. But the circumstances must be taken as a whole, and must be viewed as at the time the bargain was made": Lord Dunedin, Public Works Commissioner v Hills [1906] AC 368 at 375–6 , applying Clydebank Engineering & Shipbuilding Co v Don José Ramos Yzquierdo Y Castaneda [1905] AC 6 ; see also PC Developments Pty Ltd v Revell (1991) 22 NSWLR 615 . For an instance where the payment of a defined recoverable amount payable upon the hirer's default under a hire purchase agreement was held not to be a penalty see Esanda Finance Corp Ltd v Plessnig (1989) 166 CLR 131; 84 ALR 99 . "The question whether a sum stipulated is penalty or liquidated damages is a question of construction to be decided upon the terms and inherent circumstances of each particular contract, judged as at the time of the making of the contract, not as at the time of breach": Lord Dunedin, in Dunlop Pneumatic Tyre Co Ltd v New Garage and Motor Co Ltd [1915] AC 79 at 86–7; [1914-15] All ER Rep 739 . The words used are not decisive — the question is “not of word or of forms of speech, but of substance and of things”: Lord Radcliffe in Campbell Discount Co Ltd v Bridges [1961] 1 QB 445; [1961] 2 All ER 97 ; see also O'Dea v All States Leasing System (WA) Pty Ltd (1983) 152 CLR 359; 45 ALR 632; BC8300062 , a case involving an agreement for the hire of a truck which provided that the entire rent for the term of the hire was due at the commencement thereof, and entitled the lessor in the event of the lessee's breach to retain possession of the vehicle and sue for the total rent with no credit for accelerated payment and no credit for the proceeds of sale of the vehicle. It was held by the majority that the amount claimed constituted a penalty since it arose only upon the lessee's breach of the terms of the agreement, and the amount the lessor was entitled to receive was manifestly excessive in comparison with the greatest loss it could possibly suffer. The conclusion that a penalty clause in a contract is unenforceable does no more than deny to a party the right to recover damages in terms of that clause; it does not deprive him of his right to claim damages for the breach of that clause or for the repudiation of the contract, even if the amount of those damages is equal to or greater than the amount referred to in the penalty clause: W & J Investments v Bunting [1984] 1 NSWLR 331 ; Interoffice Telephones Ltd v Robert Freeman & Co Ltd [1958] 1 QB 190; [1957] 3 All ER 479 and Robophone Facilities Ltd v Blank [1966] 3 All ER 128; [1966] 1 WLR 1428 .

As to the above principles see also IAC (Leasing) Ltd v Humphrey (1972) 126 CLR 131; 46 ALJR 106 ; Shevill v Builders' Licensing Board (1982) 149 CLR 620; 42 ALR 305; BC8200097 ; W & J Investments v Bunting, above; Citicorp Australia v Hendry (1985) 4 NSWLR 1 ; AMEV-UDC Finance Ltd v Austin (1986) 162 CLR 170; 68 ALR 185; BC8601381 . Whilst primacy should be given "to the parties' freedom to settle for themselves their rights and liabilities following a breach of contract except to the extent that unconscionable or oppressive obligations are imposed upon one party" (AMEV Finance Ltd v Artes Studios Thoroughbreds Pty Ltd (1989) 15 NSWLR 564 at 572 per Clarke JA), the question to be asked is whether the obligation which attaches to the other party upon termination is out of all proportion, extravagant, exorbitant or unconscionable, having regard to the loss likely to be suffered by the plaintiff: Esanda Finance Corp Ltd v Plessnig, above, at 141–2, 143, 148; O'Dea v All States Leasing System (WA) Pty Ltd, above, at 400 per Deane J; Beneficial Finance Corp Ltd v Sharker (1993) 32 NSWLR 161; BC9303887 . The plaintiff still has an obligation to mitigate his loss, but that obligation is qualified where the lessor is in the business of rental, and the supply of goods hired out exceeds the demand for it: Interoffice Telephones Ltd v Robert Freeman & Co Ltd, above; Robophone Facilities Ltd v Blank, above; Thompson v Robinson [1955] Ch 177 ; McGregor H, McGregor on Damages, (15th ed), Sweet & Maxwell, London, 1988, para 859–60; Rossiter CJ, Penalties and Forfeiture, Law Book Co, 1992, p 87. “The reason is simple. The position of the lessor, in a market where supply exceeds demand, is that it is left with one less leased chattel than would be the case if there had been no repudiation, and it is deprived of the profit it would have received from a further transaction": Beneficial Finance Corp Ltd v Sharker, above, at 18.
